title: Lee Sin is still around 18% play rate
body:
For all you people that don't know, _that high-ass playrate_ is the cause of his lower winrate.

Lee Sin isn't weak, nor is he """out of meta""" - or else he would be passed up for """more superior picks""" and not maintain the highest jungler playrate.

Edit: Let's make this even more clear, because people are throwing around the phrase "fun to play" like nobody's business.

If Lee was legitimately in the dumpster, doing little to no damage and being easy as fuck to kill - despite all of his hyper-mobile shenanigans - that wouldn't be fun, now would it?
Regardless of how interesting or unique a playstyle, if it doesn't actually work, it's not going to be appreciated.

Lee Sin has always been effective, hence why he's always been "fun to play", hence why he's always been meta.

replies.body: Lee is kinda out of meta now, but not because he is bad, it's because he is not a {{item:3193}} {{item:3190}} {{item:1413}} {{item:3109}}  champion (usually)
What part of "highest jungler playrate" did you not get?
Playrate is not the same as Most Effective Tactic Available

I don't know where this backronym originated. But that's not what meta means. 

Meta is short for [metagame](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metagaming), which means "factors beyond the written rules". It's a math term. E.g. ADC/Support bottom lane  is "meta" because while Riot incentives this, nothing in the game strictly enforces it. (I recently saw a Lux/Thresh combo in flex queue). 

Lee Sin is indeed part of the metagame. While he may not be optimal, he is popular. Therefore you need to take into account the possibility that an ally or opponent will pick him. Riot doesn't force anyone to pick Lee Sin, but you still need to consider the occurrence.

> Most Effective Tactic Available

That's the stupidest thing I've ever heard
and also not what meta means...
hehe xd
Thank goodness we're talking about metagaming and not "Most Effective Tactic Available."

also, the guy that's accurately explaining why Lee Sin is picked so often is getting downvotes, sadly.

well how is lee's kit exploitable

and how is Lee not fun, champions with a lot of mobility tend to be champions that are played for fun regardless of other things

he said that play rate doesnt make a champion good or bad because they can be fun and attract players like lee is and u said that hes strong because he has a high playrate picking out 1 sentence then ignoring the rest please delete this post if u  only want to circle jerk

He said "Playrate doesn't mean shit" and "Lee is out of meta".

I said "If he had no place in the meta, he wouldn't have the highest jungler playrate."

I'm not circle-jerking, I'm pointing out very simple flaws in logic.

> [{quoted}](name=Face The Win,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=BewWgsW2,comment-id=000100000001,timestamp=2017-09-06T00:50:35.804+0000)
>
> Because he's fun[...]
> 
> Playrate doesn't mean shit
> You could gut Yasuo and people would still play the shit out of him[...]

League players, or gamers in general, for the very most part have a track record of flocking to the most OP shits in sight instead of trying to be the most loyal to their initial preference. We should know this by now. If you want proof just check out the rise and fall of fotm and meta champs, and how quick they can get spammed after pros use them or that how fast they can tank their play rate because of a nerf, or something.

"Fun" argument only holds so much weight. We know what kind of animals gamers are, please don't kid yourself.

Hence, a bigger factor in question is less to do about the arbitrary "fun", but the pragmatic effectiveness (as well as say, players agency in a sense that how much "control" them have in any given situation).

And it kinda shows a problem, just like how Lee was NOT in the Devourer meta but was still equally competitive nevertheless anyway, Lee is not in the Knight's Vow meta but is still equally competitive regardless. Now consider unlike Dota's balance, here in League you just either swim or sink with the rise and fall of meta shifts (Riot's balance philosophy would require another thread). So it really proves that his kit is just fundamentally broken that can not be not useful no matter the meta currently running rampant. And it shows Lee's a big trouble, as it has been proved and said for eons.

"Staple" or not, Lee really needs to get some revision and rework done about him. Big or small, doesn't matter. Something. Because his kit's problem lies in the core design hence it can only be fixed by touching his core design one way or the other.

so what do you suggest, if you believe his kit is broken because "he works" in meta's that allegedly don't support him

Your argument is flawed because you assume that a champion's viability, or OPness, is defined by its place within a perceived meta. This is simply not true, particularly not with metas that aren't  "do or die", much what the cinderhulmeta is. He's a completely fine pick, just as many other allegedly non meta champions are fine picks.

I know and understand better than you think about fun vs fotm and player loyalty. In generic terms, this applies, sure. However there are some cases where fun actually really beats out fotm. Lee is not a "favourite of some", the way old poppy was, that had some small fanbase that would play her no matter how much she sucked, how much she did not fit any meta. He carries a really big gathering behind him because the champion, much like yasuo, and someone mentioned lucian, feels really GOOD to play. He's unique, his kit is unique, the skill requirement to play him to a certain level unique and honestly very satisfactory. Not playing Lee myself, even I can understand this. There's only very few of such champs, and with those, no matter how much you nerf them, they'll always be played. It's pretty hard with these champions to gauge power relative to how much they're played. 

Saying he's "broken" just cause he's being played in alleged out-of -meta scenarios is too easy. Particularly because, EVEN if it was a do or die meta, you're looking at a playerbase with vastly different skill levels. I can only assume that by most played jungler, we're looking at generic player base samples, not just the actual players with a clue.

Reworking him, like there are plans for yasuo, is really rough. Where you can look at several parts of yasuo's kit to make him less irritating to play against, without gutting the feel of the champion, lee really doesn't have these options. To compare: yasuo is defined by 1) hasaki 2) dashing thru minions 3) his ult and maybe 4) arguably his windwall. What makes him frustrating is 1) his movement shield, 2) windwall, 3) dashing through minions. Already here you can alleviate two of the three problems by small reworks and touches in his abilities without completely gutting the idea of teh champ. Heck, even if you REMOVE windwall and shield, you still have yasuo. 
Now take Lee. He is defined by three things: 1) mobility, 2) insec like plays, basically his ult and 3) his q. What I can only assume people find annoying is 1) insec like plays 2) his q? and the damage? and 3) his mobility. Touch anything in Lee, and you risk the gutting I mentioned before. Touch his q, may as well remake a whole new champion and name him Luu Sun, because Lee is no more. Touch his ult, see the q. Then you have the mobility, his W to allies and his wardhops. Sure, you can nerf that. Remove wardhop and you'll need to compensate, because we all know that without that, Lee essentially becomes useless. Sure, we can look at his shielding-friendlies thing. But even if that is nerfed or even removed, will teh champion really feel less annoying to you? If Lee is a problem, then  fixing him also is, which is why I asked you "what do you suggest".

To sum up what I think, I don't think Lee is broken or a problem. You can ward well against him, you can pick into him, you can play correct against him, you can outplay him. His damage is not ridiculous, but if you get combo'd you can expect to suffer for it, much like with a plethora of other champions in this game. He's not obscure, he doesn't have tooltips the size of the newest game of thrones script to go with, or abilities that make you wonder wtf just happened. He's straightforward for both player and enemy and yet has a lot of depth. I find Lee, if anything, really balanced exactly because he works no matter where and no matter what without feeling oppressive.

> Your argument is flawed because you assume that a champion's viability, or OPness, is defined by its place within a perceived meta. This is simply not true, particularly not with metas that aren't "do or die", much what the cinderhulmeta is. He's a completely fine pick, just as many other allegedly non meta champions are fine picks.

Why do you think there hasn't been a legitimate alternative meta for the past 6+ years in League's entire lifespan of 8 or so (messing around in low elo and solo queue is NOT "legitimate")? When Riot says something is meta, that something IS meta, and there's very little you can do about it. League's balancing is NOT dynamic at all, that's the reality of League's balancing; we have almost the entirety of this game's history to back this claim up and no one can dispute it.

Your entire argument is invalid because everything you bank on is derived from the sentiment that contradicts the above statement.

What I'm saying is simple, in this kind of environment where you either sink or swim according to the demand of the meta shift (which is true), where Lee remains not only viable but also average to strong at the very least in all of the meta to date, shows that Lee has fundamental issues.

> what do you suggest

I do not need to be the solver of issues, I only need to point it out since Riot has turned a blind eye to it for the last many years that's almost as long as the game's entire lifespan. And if I actually have the grand solution then I won't be here in the first place as I would already be working in Riot already.

Lee was an Apirl Fools joke for christ sake. He's kit IS BS, he was MADE TO BE SUCH FOR THE JOKE. I have no idea why they're still keeping him around because the dude clearly has issues in his core, and that should be reworked ages ago. 

I mean, when you have a champ that can be easily proven to be trouble, for the longest time has been a gigantic stick in the asshole, remains viable and strong in metas that doesn't favour or even counters him, and after a billion nerfs still remain a ticking time-bomb ready to go off, but can not be touched meaningfully or else they become hot garbage... Doesn't that signify that this champ is fundamentally questionable and should be remade?
Once that whole ''ADC es numero one'' meta is over, we will all regret those buffs.

Or he's just a fun champion to main with a large and dedicated playbase

he's always had one of the highest play-rates in the game. *always*, even when he was trash tier (yes, that *has* happened). To pretend like people only play champions because they're the best is such a large jump that ignores so many factors is ridiculous.

This to be honest. He's very beginner "magnetic" since he doesn't use mana and his super forgiving while also looking pretty "flashy" when he does stuff. He's just a fun character to play as, so even if he is weak people will play him. Do I think the buff they are giving him now is correct? Hell no. Lee Sin does not need more early game power. Do I think he could use some help? Maybe.

He could be gutted to a 30% win rate overall and he'd still have a high play rate. Other champs that are played regardless of power/if they are meta or not are Riven, Yasuo, Vayne, Ez to name a few because they are mechanically challenging and fun to main
Ezreal currently has a pretty average play rate to be honest. The recent patch really proves this wrong. Riven, Yasuo, and Vayne will be seen a ton though.

Until recently he has gotten some buffs but i think riot realized their mistake so they aren't just going to put lee on the chopping block just because people like to play him. Just my thoughts. Have a great day everyone!

(This is satire. I can't believe I actually might have explain a joke, but if it comes to that, I will).

In all serious though, Lee Sin's playrate is so high because he's one of the most fun champions to play in the game. Right now we are in a tank meta. Lee sin probably won't be played till tank itemization gets nerfed and picks like elise and nidalee come back.

Considering that Maokai is horrendously outclassed by Sejuani, there's really only 4 tanks in the meta right now with the sole unifying factor being that they were reworked after the tank update.

So it's ok when you categorize lee as an overpowered jungler because of his pick rate but not when I do it. K.

I never called him "overpowered", just meta and consistently effective. You said "top 5 champions", which op.gg doesn't present, instead of "top 5 _picked_ champions _in jungle_" or "top 5 _winning_ champions _in top_".

In Korea, Sejuani is at 55/11%, then Rammus at 53/4%, and then Cho is at 52/3%, making the only tank worth picking at a high elo Korean level: Sejuani (Who is a hard counter to Lee Sin at 47/22%)

I know Lee Sin falls into that class but his kit basically trascends the melee standard sort of like Fizz and Olaf (mainly Olaf as Fizz is "supposed" to be squishy)

The assassin rework initially looked good to me until it turns out Riot isn't serious about letting assassins be competitive despite their supposedly increased skillcap
Lee is in a good spot right now;  I really don't want his state to change... ever
